title.narrative: GLA - West Sumatra, West Kalimantan and Central Sulawesi Provinces in Indonesia

description.narrative: During 2017, TBI Indonesia will work with CSOs in the Gunung Tarak Landscape in West Kalimantan Province to contribute to improved landscape level conservation planning and implementation, and improve the natural resource governance of forest lands that have been allocated to villages and communities. Related activities will be carried with other GLA partners in Mudiak Baduo Landscape (West Sumatra) and Lariang Landscape (Central Sulawesi). The focus of landscape conservation planning (LCP) will be to develop a large scale vision of conservation and development priorities in Gunung Tarak Landscape based on the High Conservation Value (HCV) approach. The map will be used as a basis for CSOs to coordinate their strategies, and influence government and oil palm companies to establish, conserve and manage high value areas in a coherent way including designing Essential Ecosystem Areas (EEA), ecological corridors, inter-villages forest protection. We will enhance knowledge and capacities of CSOs, CBOs and government actors on the HCV concept and identification through training, facilitation and technical assistance. With regard to local level natural resource governance, we will work with CSO partners to facilitate bottom-up spatial planning in three villages located in the corridor area between two remaining forest blocks. We will collaborate with CBOs and oil-palm management units to facilitate the establishment of inter-village regulations to manage forests sustainably. We will also support villages to manage their newly established village-managed forests; at the same time, we support community and villages governments to apply for village forests rights. Most activities will be carried out as a coalition with CSOs and CBOs; we will support joint planning, coordination and learning in the coalition to pursue our goals. We will build our own capacities in implementing policy influencing strategies, communication skills, engagement with private sector actors, coalition building and gender issues.

Indonesia accounts for the third largest forest area in the world (ca. 127 million ha) , with designated forest lands covering 60% of its land area, yet it also has one of the highest rates of deforestation globally (around 1.17 million ha per year). To date, economic growth has been sustained through a strategy which builds on the use of Indonesia’s abundant natural resources. Commodities comprise more than half of exports, and agriculture (15%) and mining (12%) are key contributors to the national Gross Domestic Product. Agriculture and forests are vital for livelihoods, and employ more than a third of the working population. Millions of people (33,000 villages) depend on the forest and forest commodities for their livelihood without any recognition of access and/or use of the natural resources. However, in 2015, the government launched an ambitious program targeted at allocating 12.7 million hectares of forests to be managed by communities through social forestry schemes, more than 2.5 million hectares each year. The GLA partners in Indonesia have selected three landscapes which represent the general problems and livelihoods strategies in the country very well: ‘Mudiak Baduo’ in the West Sumatra Province, ‘Gunung Tarak’ in the West Kalimantan Province and ‘Lariang’ in the Central Sulawesi Province. The three landscapes face the following shared issues: (1) a rapid expansion of agro-commodity oil palm and other land-based investments at the expense of forests; (2) tenure insecurity and long arduous bureaucratic procedures for obtaining Social Forestry (SF) permits; (3) uncertainty about what communities will do with their SF permits and how they will use forest environmental services to create better lives; and (4) lack of forest-based sustainable livelihood options surrounding conservation areas which has led to rampant illegal logging and encroachment.

The outcomes envisaged by GLA in Indonesia contribute to the three overall conditions for sustainable and inclusive governance of forested landscapes as described in the international ToC for the GLA: (a) security of land tenure/access to land and resources use for local communities, addressed through interventions related to Village Forestry and community participation in the management of plantations; (b) communities and CSOs included in decision making on land use throughout, through collaboration or through access by justice; (c) implementation of nature based approaches to the management of forested landscapes in the implementation of sustainable management of village forests, and of the High Conservation Value (HCV) approach in the spatial planning of land investments. This is to be achieved by strengthening CSO capacities for lobbying and advocacy for (1) equitable and sustainable spatial planning; (2) the application of HCV as the key tool for sustainable production investments and regional development by private sector and government to; (3) sustainable management of oil palm concessions, and sustainable palm oil supply chains; (4) supporting village governments and community groups in equal participation in sustainable agro-industry; and (5) local communities to have a greater involvement in the sustainable management of forest areas.

3. Oil palm growers sustainably manage their concession, while traders/buyers conduct sustainable trade
Change in level of participation/ capacity/ operational space of civil actors in landscape governance, access to land (rights) and nature-based approaches

description.narrative: The level on the Civil Actor Participation (CAP) tool demonstrating a change in the participation/ capacity/ operational space of civil actors: scale 1 = no participation. no capacity to influence/participate. no operational space. 2 = passive participation (informed). limited capacity to influence/participate. limited operational space. 3 = small scale/piloting participation. some capacity to influence/participate. some operational space. 4 = involvement/active participation. capacity to actively influence/participate. more favourable operational space. 5 =partnership/collaboration. capacity, means and operational space to influence or participate as equal partners.6 = leading role for civil actors. civil actors fully capacitated and acknowledged for having the leading role in a safe, conducive operational space. A more detailed description of this scle can be found in the added CAP tool (pdf).

comment.narrative: CSOs have no capacity to map supply chain of oil palm traders
CSOs coalition in GTL enable to develop map of Oil palm supply chain which will be used as a basis for L&A
No outcomes in 2017
GLA partner started L&A for oil palm moratorium at national level while CSOs coalition at GTL oversee supply chain of big oil palm traders

title.narrative: The level of engagement, commitment and action (ECA) of the targeted public or private actor.

description.narrative: The level on the ECA tool demonstrating a change in the policies/practices/behaviour of targeted public and private actors. Scale: 1 = no interest, 2 = awareness and receptiveness, 3 = agenda setting, 4 = concrete steps to improvement, 5 = improved policies, guidelines, etc. approved, 6 = poor implementation (of good policies, laws, etc.), 7 = moderate implementation., 8 = satisfactory implementation. A more detailed description of this scale can be found in the added ECA tool (pdf).

comment.narrative: Considerable proportion of palm oil traders supply chains are still linked to deforestation.
no entry for IATI in 2017
No outcomes in 2017
Oil palm plantations in Indonesia have better compliance with national legislation and sustainability standards

title.narrative: 2. Private sector and government use HCV as the key tool for sustainable production investment and regional development
The level of engagement, commitment and action (ECA) of the targeted public or private actor.

description.narrative: The level on the ECA tool demonstrating a change in the policies/practices/behaviour of targeted public and private actors. Scale: 1 = no interest, 2 = awareness and receptiveness, 3 = agenda setting, 4 = concrete steps to improvement, 5 = improved policies, guidelines, etc. approved, 6 = poor implementation (of good policies, laws, etc.), 7 = moderate implementation., 8 = satisfactory implementation. A more detailed description of this scale can be found in the added ECA tool (pdf).

comment.narrative: HCV (high conservation value) area allocation has been in place but poorly defined, connected and managed
Some oil palm MUs have started to improve HCV allocation and management at MU and landscape level in GTL

Three oil palm companies gave their commitment in the form of MoU signed with Tropenbos Indonesia to do collaborative activities in the Gunung Tarak Landscape. The companies have already improved the management of their HCV areas and have agreed to align their HCV areas as part of the proposed corridors established to connect Sungai Putri peatland forest – Gunung Palung National Park – Gunung Tarak Protection Forest. The oil palm MUs of PT KAL has involved the Laman Satong village government and community to protect and manage their HCV areas.
2.1. Private sector use HCV as the key tool for sustainable production investment in oil palm and other commodities in GTL.

title.narrative: The level of engagement, commitment and action (ECA) of the targeted public or private actor.

description.narrative: The level on the ECA tool demonstrating a change in the policies/practices/behaviour of targeted public and private actors. Scale: 1 = no interest, 2 = awareness and receptiveness, 3 = agenda setting, 4 = concrete steps to improvement, 5 = improved policies, guidelines, etc. approved, 6 = poor implementation (of good policies, laws, etc.), 7 = moderate implementation., 8 = satisfactory implementation. A more detailed description of this scale can be found in the added ECA tool (pdf).

comment.narrative: MoEF is in the process of formulating and issuing Ministerial decree on EEA (essential ecosystem areas)
MoEF and Provincial Forestry Services identify and establish EEA in GLA Landscapes (GTL, MB, LW).

The District Development and Planning Agency (Bappeda) of Ketapang has adopted the HCV approach as part of implementation of the Essential Ecosystem Area (EEA/KEE) and the provincial government has released Governor Decree No.718 year 2017 about KEE (EEA) dated 17 November 2017 in which the ecological corridors of orangutan proposed by Tropenbos Indonesia has also been incorporated.
2.2. Central and regional government respect HCV implementation and oversee its implementation as part of essential ecosystem areas/EEA

title.narrative: 5. Local communities have a greater involvement in sustainable forest management
The level of engagement, commitment and action (ECA) of the targeted public or private actor.

description.narrative: The level on the ECA tool demonstrating a change in the policies/practices/behaviour of targeted public and private actors. Scale: 1 = no interest, 2 = awareness and receptiveness, 3 = agenda setting, 4 = concrete steps to improvement, 5 = improved policies, guidelines, etc. approved, 6 = poor implementation (of good policies, laws, etc.), 7 = moderate implementation., 8 = satisfactory implementation. A more detailed description of this scale can be found in the added ECA tool (pdf).

comment.narrative: MoEF have issued new Social Forestry Regulation which shortens bureaucracy on SF application. Since Law No. 23/2014 took effect in October 2016, West Kalimantan Governor plays roles on verifying and submitting the SF application to MoEF and then issuance of SFMR. SF holders currently have poor capacity to execute their workplan. Village Forestry Management Groups (VFMG) have little capacity to apply for SF permits.
MoEF decides to decentralise SF verification and permitting from central to provincial government level.
Village Forest Management Forum (Forum Hutan Desa - FHD) has succeeded in applying SF permits for four villages in Ketapang district.
Village Forest Management Groups in GTL enabled to gain Social Forestry permit and gain sustainable income from forest products and environmental services

comment.narrative: TBI and GLA partners have limited capacity to conduct L&A at national level
TBI and GLA partners have capacity to conduct L & A on SF issues
No outcomes in 2017
GLA partners started L&A to shorten SF licensing procedure while CSO coalition in GTL strengthen SF holders to execute their workplan

title.narrative: 4. Village government and community groups participate and are equally involved in sustainable agro-industry
Change in level of participation/ capacity/ operational space of civil actors in landscape governance, access to land (rights) and nature-based approaches

description.narrative: The level on the Civil Actor Participation (CAP) tool demonstrating a change in the participation/ capacity/ operational space of civil actors: scale 1 = no participation. no capacity to influence/participate. no operational space. 2 = passive participation (informed). limited capacity to influence/participate. limited operational space. 3 = small scale/piloting participation. some capacity to influence/participate. some operational space. 4 = involvement/active participation. capacity to actively influence/participate. more favourable operational space. 5 =partnership/collaboration. capacity, means and operational space to influence or participate as equal partners.6 = leading role for civil actors. civil actors fully capacitated and acknowledged for having the leading role in a safe, conducive operational space. comment.narrative: CSOs have no capacity to facilitate village government to develop Green-RPJM Desa
CSOs in GTL enable to facilitate village government to develop Green-RPJM Desa and inter-villages regulation to protect forested landscape.

(1) The women group Bedau Jaya in Laman Satong village that was established on 20 July 2017 has started horticulture farming by planting different food crops to supply their own needs and also for sale and has started an oyster mushrooms business. (2) Village community in Sungai Putri and Ulak Medang took part in the formulation and review of RPJM Desa
CSO coalition in GTL trained and facilitated VGs to develop and implement Mid-term (5 years) Green Village Planning (Green-RPJM Desa)

title.narrative: The level of engagement, commitment and action (ECA) of the targeted public or private actor.

description.narrative: The level on the ECA tool demonstrating a change in the policies/practices/behaviour of targeted public and private actors. Scale: 1 = no interest, 2 = awareness and receptiveness, 3 = agenda setting, 4 = concrete steps to improvement, 5 = improved policies, guidelines, etc. approved, 6 = poor implementation (of good policies, laws, etc.), 7 = moderate implementation., 8 = satisfactory implementation. A more detailed description of this scale can be found in the added ECA tool (pdf).

comment.narrative: Most villages have not developed green village planning (Green-RPJM Desa) based on thorough analysis of their natural resource problems and potentials, while all villages have not developed inter-villages regulations to protect forested landscape. HCV areas in oil palm MU are therefore not used sustainably for village development
Three VGs hold capacity to develop Green-RPJM Desa and inter-villages regulations to protect forested landscape (Kawasan Perlindungan Desa)

(1) The Village Government of Laman Satong has developed alternative livelihoods and collaborates with private companies. Oil palm company PT KAL has provided funding to build mushroom house to cultivate oyster mushrooms managed by the women group Bedau Jaya in Laman Satong Village. (2) By December 2017 Village Governments of Sungai Putri and Ulak Medang villages have started to include green policy in the ongoing revision of its village mid-term development plan (RPJM Des)
Village Goverments in GTL enabled to develop sustainable livelihoods from their forests in collaboration with Oil-Palm MU and beyond

title.narrative: 6. GLA partners in GTL have learned to organize themselves into strong coalition
Change in level of participation/ capacity/ operational space of civil actors in landscape governance, access to land (rights) and nature-based approaches

comment.narrative: There are several CSOs and CBOs operational in GTL. Their efforts are currently relatively scattered and not supported by a common vision or regular strategic alignment of activities
CSOs in GTL have capacity to work together as coalition
The WhatsApp Group Tropen Forum has grown to be an effective forum to share information among members and strengthen networking at the landscape.
CSOs and CBOs in GTL regularly update each other about strategies, hold a common landscape vision, and jointly determine influencing strategies on selected topics

title.narrative: 1. Spatial planning to become more inclusive, equitable and sustainable
Change in level of participation/ capacity/ operational space of civil actors in landscape governance, access to land (rights) and nature-based approaches

description.narrative: The level on the Civil Actor Participation (CAP) tool demonstrating a change in the participation/ capacity/ operational space of civil actors: scale 1 = no participation. no capacity to influence/participate. no operational space. 2 = passive participation (informed). limited capacity to influence/participate. limited operational space. 3 = small scale/piloting participation. some capacity to influence/participate. some operational space. 4 = involvement/active participation. capacity to actively influence/participate. more favourable operational space. 5 =partnership/collaboration. capacity, means and operational space to influence or participate as equal partners.6 = leading role for civil actors. civil actors fully capacitated and acknowledged for having the leading role in a safe, conducive operational space. comment.narrative: CSOs facilitations at village level have not touched natural resource governance issues
1.1 CSOs in GTL enabled to facilitate PM,PCP and RTRW Desa in three villages and inter-villages spatial planning.

Community members of Laman Staong and Pangkalan Jihing villages, including youth, have developed PM and PCP. The Laman Satong village has contributed to the development of its villages spatial planning.
1.1: CSOs coalition(s) in GTL landscapes are facilitating villages to develop PM,PCP and RTRW Desa as a basis for bottom-up spatial planning.

title.narrative: The level of engagement, commitment and action (ECA) of the targeted public or private actor.

description.narrative: The level on the ECA tool demonstrating a change in the policies/practices/behaviour of targeted public and private actors. Scale: 1 = no interest, 2 = awareness and receptiveness, 3 = agenda setting, 4 = concrete steps to improvement, 5 = improved policies, guidelines, etc. approved, 6 = poor implementation (of good policies, laws, etc.), 7 = moderate implementation., 8 = satisfactory implementation. A more detailed description of this scale can be found in the added ECA tool (pdf).

comment.narrative: Within new village Law, village governments (VG) are entitled to define their natural resource design and allocation, but most VGs have not taken initiative due to lack of awareness and capacity.
Some (3) selected Village Governments (VG) in GTL develop village spatial planning (RTRW Desa) as a basis for bottom-up spatial planning in the landscape

Laman Satong village government has used results of Participatory Mapping (PM) and Participatory Conservation Planning (PCP) as a basis for village spatial planning and natural resource management strategies. The community has now marked their village boundaries, developed a database of types of land use and identified HCV in their areas.
Village government enable to develop village spatial planning as a basis for bottom-up spatial planning in the landscape and the iniatives are respected by District Government.
